sen.j: 阿加流比売神（あかるひめのかみ）は、日本神話に登場する神 (神道)である。
sen.e: "Akaru-hime" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.
"Akaru-hime" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.
Akaru-hime is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: 『古事記』では新羅王の子であるアメノヒボコ（あめのひぼこ）の妻となっている。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), she is the wife of Amenohiboko, the child of the King of Silla.
In "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), she is the wife of Amenohiboko, the child of the King of Silla.
In "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), she is the wife of Amenohiboko, the child of the King of Silla.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では伽耶王の子である都怒我阿羅斯等（つぬがあらしと）が追いかける童女（名の記述はない）のエピソード同一である。
sen.e: It is the same as the episode in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) of the warawame (a little girl, name not described) whom Tsunugaarashito, the child of the King of Gaya chases.
sen.cmt: 「エピソード同一である」は「エピソードと同一である」と解釈しました
sen.e: It is the same as the episode in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) of the warawame (a little girl, name not described) whom Tsunugaarashito, the child of the King of Gaya chases.
It is the same as the episode in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) of the warawame (a little girl, name not described) whom Tsunugaarashito, the child of the King of Gaya chases.

sen.j: 記紀で国や夫や女の名は異なっているが、両者の説話の内容は大変似通っている。
sen.e: The names of country, husband, and women differ between the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), but the setsuwa (anecdote) in them are very similar.
The names of country, husband, and women differ between the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), but the setsuwa (anecdote) in them are very similar.
The names of country, husband, and women differ between the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), but the setsuwa (anecdote) in them are very similar.

sen.j: 『古事記』では応神天皇記に記述がある。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," it is described in the Ojin Tenno ki.
In "Kojiki," it is described in the Ojin Tenno ki.
In "Kojiki," it is described in the Ojin Tenno ki.

sen.j: 昔、新羅のアグヌマ（阿具奴摩、阿具沼）という沼で女が昼寝をしていると、その陰部に日の光が虹のようになって当たった。
sen.e: Long time ago, a woman was taking a nap at a marsh called Agunuma Pond, the sunlight shined on her genitals like a rainbow.
A long time ago, a woman was taking a nap at a marsh called Agunuma Pond, the sunlight shined on her genitals like a rainbow.
A long time ago, a woman was taking a nap at a marsh called Agunuma Pond in Silla, the sunlight shined on her genitals like a rainbow.

sen.j: すると女はたちまち娠んで、赤い玉を産んだ。
sen.e: The woman became pregnant at once, and gave birth to a red ball.
The woman became pregnant at once, and gave birth to a red ball.
The woman became pregnant at once, and gave birth to a red ball.

sen.j: その様子を見ていた男は乞い願ってその玉を貰い受け、肌身離さず持ち歩いていた。
sen.e: A man who was watching this asked for and was given the ball, and always carried it with him.
A man who was watching this asked for and was given the ball, and always carried it with him.
A man who was watching this asked for and was given the ball, and always carried it with him.

sen.j: ある日、男が牛で食べ物を山に運んでいる途中、天之日矛と出会った。
sen.e: One day, when the man was carrying food to the mountain on a cow, he met Amenohiboko.
One day, when the man was carrying food to the mountain on a cow, he met Amenohiboko.
One day, when the man was carrying food to the mountain on a cow, he met Amenohiboko.

sen.j: 天之日矛は、男が牛を殺して食べるつもりだと勘違いして捕えて牢獄に入れようとした。
sen.e: Amenohiboko had the illusion that the man wanted to kill and eat the cow, so he captured him and tried to imprison him.
Amenohiboko had the illusion that the man wanted to kill and eat the cow, so he captured him and tried to imprison him.
Amenohiboko had the illusion that the man wanted to kill and eat the cow, so he captured him and tried to imprison him.

sen.j: 男が釈明をしても天之日矛は許さなかったので、男はいつも持ち歩いていた赤い玉を差し出して、ようやく許してもらえた。
sen.e: Since Amenohiboko would not accept the man's explanation, he offered the red ball which he always carried, and was finally excused.
Since Amenohiboko would not accept the man's explanation, he offered the red ball which he always carried, and was finally excused.
Since Amenohiboko would not accept the man's explanation, he offered the red ball which he always carried, and was finally excused.

sen.j: 天之日矛がその玉を持ち帰って床に置くと、玉は美しい娘になった。
sen.e: When Amenohiboko brought home the ball and placed it on the floor, the ball turned into a beautiful girl.
When Amenohiboko brought home the ball and placed it on the floor, the ball turned into a beautiful girl.
When Amenohiboko brought home the ball and placed it on the floor, the ball turned into a beautiful girl.

sen.j: 天之日矛は娘を正妻とし、娘は毎日美味しい料理を出していた。
sen.e: Amenohiboko made the girl his legal wife, and the girl served him delicious dishes every day.
Amenohiboko made the girl his legal wife, and the girl served him delicious dishes every day.
Amenohiboko made the girl his legal wife, and the girl served him delicious dishes every day.

sen.j: しかし、ある日奢り高ぶった天之日矛が妻を罵ったので、親の国に帰ると言って小舟に乗って難波の津に逃げてきた。
sen.e: However, when Amenohiboko became very arrogant and scolded the wife one day, she fled by boat to Tsu in Nanba, saying she is returning to her parents' home.
However, when Amenohiboko became very arrogant and scolded the wife one day, she fled by boat to Tsu in Nanba, saying she was returning to her parents' home.
However, when Amenohiboko became very arrogant and scolded the wife one day, she fled by boat to Tsu in Nanba, saying she was returning to her parents' home.

sen.j: その娘は、難波の比売碁曾の社に鎮まる阿加流比売神であるという。
sen.e: The girl is said to be Akaru-hime who is enshrined at Himegoso-sha Shrine in Nanba.
The girl is said to be Akaru-hime who is enshrined at Himegoso-sha Shrine in Nanba.
The girl is said to be Akaru-hime who is enshrined at Himegoso-sha Shrine in Nanba.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では垂仁天皇記に記述がある。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki," it is described in the Suinin Tenno ki.
In "Nihonshoki," it is described in the Suinin Tenno ki.
In "Nihonshoki," it is described in the Suinin Tenno ki.

sen.j: 都怒我阿羅斯等は自分の牛に荷物を背負わせて田舎へ行ったが、牛が急にいなくなってしまった。
sen.e: Tsunugaarashito went to the country with his cow carrying his luggage, but the cow suddenly disappeared.
Tsunugaarashito went to the country with his cow carrying his luggage, but the cow suddenly disappeared.
Tsunugaarashito went to the country with his cow carrying his luggage, but the cow suddenly disappeared.

sen.j: 足跡を追って村の中に入ると、その村の役人が、「この荷の内容からすると、この牛の持ち主はこの牛を食べようとしているのだろう」と言って食べてしまったという。
sen.e: When he followed its steps to the village, the officer in the village ate the cow saying 'judging from the contents of this luggage, the owner of this cow intends to eat this cow.'
When he followed its steps to the village, the officer in the village ate the cow saying 'judging from the contents of this luggage, the owner of this cow intends to eat this cow.'
When he followed its steps to the village, the officer in the village ate the cow saying 'judging from the contents of this luggage, the owner of this cow intends to eat this cow.'

sen.j: 都怒我阿羅斯等は牛の代償として、その村で神として祀られている白い石を譲り受けた。
sen.e: To compensate for the cow, Tsunugaarashito was given a white stone which was enshrined in the village as god.
In compensatation for the cow, Tsunugaarashito was given a white stone which was enshrined in the village as god.
In compensation for the cow, Tsunugaarashito was given a white stone which was enshrined in the village as god.

sen.j: 石を持ち帰って寝床に置くと、石は美しい娘になった。
sen.e: When he brought the stone home and placed it on his bed, the stone turned into a beautiful girl.
When he brought the stone home and placed it on his bed, the stone turned into a beautiful girl.
When he brought the stone home and placed it on his bed, the stone turned into a beautiful girl.

sen.j: 都怒我阿羅斯等が喜んで娘と性交しようとしたが、目を離したすきに娘はいなくなってしまった。
sen.e: Tsunugaarashito was delighted and tried to have intercourse with the girl, but the girl disappeared while he took his eyes off of her.
Tsunugaarashito was delighted and tried to have intercourse with the girl, but the girl disappeared while he took his eyes off of her.
Tsunugaarashito was delighted and tried to have intercourse with the girl, but the girl disappeared while he took his eyes off of her.

sen.j: 都怒我阿羅斯等の妻によれば、娘は東の方へ行ったという。
sen.e: According to the wife of Tsunugaarashito, the girl went east.
According to the wife of Tsunugaarashito, the girl went east.
According to the wife of Tsunugaarashito, the girl went east.

sen.j: 娘は難波に至って比売語曾社の神となった。
sen.e: The girl reached Nanba and became the god of Himegoso-sha Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The girl reached Nanba and became the god of Himegoso-sha Shrine.
The girl reached Nanba and became the god of Himegoso-sha Shrine.

sen.j: また、豊国の国東郡へ至って比売語曽社の神となり、二箇所で祀られているという。
sen.e: Additionally, she reached Kunisaki County in Toyo-no-kuni and became the god of Himegoso-sha Shrine, and is enshrined in two locations.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Additionally, she reached Kunisaki County in Toyo-no-kuni and became the god of Himegoso-sha Shrine, and is enshrined in two locations.
Additionally, she reached Kunisaki County in Toyo-no-kuni and became the god of Himegoso-sha Shrine, and is enshrined in two locations.

tit.e: Unknown or lost writings of Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki
Unknown or lost writings of Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki
Unknown or lost writings of Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki

sen.j: 『摂津国風土記』逸文にも阿加流比売神と思われる神についての記述がある。
sen.e: There is description on a god believed to be Akaru-hime in the unknown or lost writings of "Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki."
There is description on a god believed to be Akaru-hime in the unknown or lost writings of "Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki."
There is description on a god believed to be Akaru-hime in the unknown or lost writings of "Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki" (records of the culture and geography of the Settsu Province).

sen.j: 応神天皇の時代、新羅にいた女神が夫から逃れて筑紫国の「伊波比の比売島」に住んでいた。
sen.e: In the era of Emperor Ojin, a goddess in Silla fled from her husband and lived in 'Himejima Island of Iwai' in Tsukushi Province.
In the era of Emperor Ojin, a goddess in Silla fled from her husband and lived in 'Himejima Island of Iwai' in Tsukushi Province.
In the era of Emperor Ojin, a goddess in Silla fled from her husband and lived in 'Himejima Island of Iwai' in Tsukushi Province.

sen.j: しかし、ここにいてはすぐに夫に見つかるだろうとその島を離れ、難波の島に至り、前に住んでいた島の名前をとって「比売島」と名附けた。
sen.e: However, she left the island fearing she would soon be found by her husband and arrived on an island in Nanba, which she named 'Himejima Island' from the name of the island where she previously lived.

However, she left the island fearing she would soon be found by her husband and arrived on an island in Nanba, which she named 'Himejima Island' from the name of the island where she previously lived.

However, she left the island fearing she would soon be found by her husband and arrived on an island in Nanba, which she named 'Himejima Island' from the name of the island where she previously lived.

sen.j: 『古事記』の阿加流比売神の出生譚は、女が日光を受けて卵を生み、そこから人間が生まれるという卵生神話の一種である。
sen.e: Tale of the birth of Akaru-hime in "Kojiki" is a type of Ransei mythology where a woman receives sunlight and lays an egg, and a person is born from there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tale of the birth of Akaru-hime in "Kojiki" is a type of Ransei mythology where a woman receives sunlight and lays an egg, and a person is born from there.
Tale of the birth of Akaru-hime in "Kojiki" is a type of Ransei mythology where a woman receives sunlight and lays an egg, and a person is born from there.

sen.j: 類似した説話が朝鮮に多く伝わっている。
sen.e: Many similar setsuwa exist in Korea.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Many similar setsuwa exist in Korea.
Many similar setsuwa exist in Korea.

sen.j: 例えば高句麗の始祖東明聖王（朱蒙）や新羅の始祖赫居世居西干、伽耶諸国のひとつ伽耶駕洛国（金官伽耶）の始祖首露王の出生譚などがそうである。
sen.e: Examples include the tales of birth of Dongmyeong-seongwang (Ju Mong), the founder of Goguryeo, Kakukyosei Kyoseikan, the founder of Silla, and Suro-wang, the founder of Kinkan kaya, one of the Gaya.
sen.cmt: 原文には (伽耶駕洛国) とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「金官国」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: Examples include the tales of birth of Dongmyeong-seongwang (Ju Mong), the founder of Goguryeo, Kakukyosei Kyoseikan, the founder of Silla, and Suro-wang, the founder of Kinkan kaya, one of the Gaya.
Examples include the tales of birth of Dongmyeong-seongwang (Ju Mong), the founder of Goguryeo, Kakukyosei Kyoseikan, the founder of Silla, and Suro-wang, the founder of Kinkan kaya, one of the Gaya.

sen.j: 『古事記』に記述された「難波の比売碁曾社」に相当する神社として大阪市東成区東小橋の比売許曽神社があるが、現在、この神社の主祭神は大国主の娘のシタテルヒメとされている。
sen.e: A shrine corresponding to 'Himegoso-sha Shrine in Nanba' described in "Kojiki" is the Himekoso-jinja Shrine in Higashiobase, Higashinari Ward, Osaka City, and today, the shusaijin (main enshrined deity) of this shrine is believed to be Shitateru-hime, the daughter of Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region).

A shrine corresponding to 'Himegoso-sha Shrine in Nanba' described in "Kojiki" is the Himekoso-jinja Shrine in Higashiobase, Higashinari Ward, Osaka City, and today, the shusaijin (main enshrined deity) of this shrine is believed to be Shitateru-hime, the daughter of Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region).

A shrine corresponding to 'Himegoso-sha Shrine in Nanba' described in "Kojiki" is the Himekoso-jinja Shrine in Higashiobase, Higashinari Ward, Osaka City, and today, the shusaijin (main enshrined deity) of this shrine is believed to be Shitateru-hime, the daughter of Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region).

sen.j: 他に、アメノワカヒコの従者であるアメノサグメと同一視されることもある。
sen.e: Additionally, she is sometimes considered the same god as Amenosagume, the follower of Amenowakahiko.
Additionally, she is sometimes considered the same god as Amenosagume, the follower of Amenowakahiko.
Additionally, she is sometimes considered the same god as Amenosagume, the follower of Amenowakahiko.

sen.j: 『摂津国風土記』逸文の比売島と同名の姫島神社が大阪市西淀川区姫島町にあり、阿迦留姫命（神社伝承による）が住吉大神とともに祀られている。
sen.e: Himejima-jinja Shrine, which has the same name as Himejima Island in the unknown or lost writings of "Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki," exists in Himeshima, Nishiyodogawa Ward, Osaka City, and Akaruhime-no-mikoto (according to tradition of the shrine) is enshrined along with Sumiyoshi Okami (the great gods of Sumiyoshi).

Himejima-jinja Shrine, which has the same name as Himejima Island in the unknown or lost writings of "Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki," exists in Himeshima, Nishiyodogawa Ward, Osaka City, and Akaruhime-no-mikoto (according to tradition of the shrine) is enshrined along with Sumiyoshi Okami (the great gods of Sumiyoshi).

Himejima-jinja Shrine, which has the same name as Himejima Island in the unknown or lost writings of "Settsu-no-kuni-fudoki," exists in Himeshima, Nishiyodogawa Ward, Osaka City, and Akaruhime-no-mikoto (according to tradition of the shrine) is enshrined along with Sumiyoshi Okami (the great gods of Sumiyoshi).

sen.j: ほかに、大阪市平野区平野東の赤留比売命神社（三十歩神社）にも阿加流比売神が祀られている。
sen.e: In addition, Akaruhimenomikoto-jinja Shrine (Sanjubu-jinja Shrine) in Hiranohigashi, Hirano Ward, Osaka City, also enshrines Akaru-hime.
In addition, Akaruhimenomikoto-jinja Shrine (Sanjubu-jinja Shrine) in Hiranohigashi, Hirano Ward, Osaka City, also enshrines Akaru-hime.
In addition, Akaruhimenomikoto-jinja Shrine (Sanjubu-jinja Shrine) in Hiranohigashi, Hirano Ward, Osaka City, also enshrines Akaru-hime.

sen.j: 「豊国の比売語曾社」は、大分県姫島村の比売語曽社である。
sen.e: Himegoso-sha Shrine in Toyo-no-kuni' is the Himekoso-sha Shrine in Himeshima-mura, Oita Prefecture.
Himegoso-sha Shrine in Toyo-no-kuni' is the Himekoso-sha Shrine in Himeshima-mura, Oita Prefecture.
Himegoso-sha Shrine in Toyo-no-kuni' is the Himekoso-sha Shrine in Himeshima-mura, Oita Prefecture.

sen.j: 『豊前国風土記』逸文にも、新羅国の神が来て河原に住んだので鹿春神というとある。
sen.e: In the unknown or lost writings of "Buzennokuni fudoki" it is described that the name Kaharu-gami came from the fact that a god from Silla came and lived on the banks.
In the unknown or lost writings of "Buzennokuni fudoki" it is described that the name Kaharu-gami came from the fact that a god from Silla came and lived on the banks.

In the unknown or lost writings of "Buzennokuni fudoki" (records of the culture and geography of the Buzen Province) it is described that the name Kaharu-gami came from the fact that a god from Silla came and lived on the banks.
